objectives: Match subjects with the correct verbs in sentences
Understand how to use verbs with singular and plural subjects
Learn to avoid common mistakes in subject-verb agreement

sections.text: Subject-verb agreement means that the subject and the verb in a sentence must match each other. If the subject is singular (one person, one animal, one thing), the verb must also be singular. If the subject is plural (more than one), the verb must also be plural. This is a very important rule in English grammar. Think of it like a pair of shoes: a left shoe and a right shoe must always go together. The subject is one shoe, and the verb is the other. They must match in number.

sections.text: Collective nouns (like 'family', 'team', 'committee', 'group') refer to a group of people or things. They can be singular or plural depending on how they are used. If the group acts as one unit, use a singular verb. If the members of the group are acting separately, use a plural verb. In most cases, especially for rural students, treating collective nouns as singular is more common and easier.

sections.text: When two or more subjects are joined by 'and', the verb is usually plural. For example, 'Ram and Shyam are friends.' When subjects are joined by 'or' or 'nor', the verb agrees with the subject closest to it. For example, 'Either Ram or his brothers are coming.' or 'Neither the children nor the teacher is here.'

sections.text: Indefinite pronouns like 'everyone', 'everybody', 'anyone', 'anybody', 'someone', 'somebody', 'no one', 'nobody', 'each', 'either', 'neither' are always singular. They take a singular verb. Words like 'all', 'some', 'any', 'none', 'most' can be singular or plural depending on what they refer to. If they refer to a countable noun, they can be plural. If they refer to an uncountable noun, they are singular.

subtopics.title: Subjects that Look Plural but are Singular

sections.text: Some words end in 's' but are actually singular and take a singular verb. These include names of subjects (mathematics, physics), diseases (measles, mumps), and some other words (news, economics). Similarly, titles of books, movies, or organizations, even if they have plural words, usually take a singular verb if they refer to one thing.

sections.text: In sentences that start with 'there is' or 'there are', the true subject comes after the verb. So, the verb must agree with the noun that comes after 'there is' or 'there are'. If the noun is singular, use 'there is'. If it is plural, use 'there are'.

subtopics.title: Mistakes with Plural-Looking Nouns (but Singular Meaning)

sections.text: Sometimes, we see words that look plural because they end in 's', but they are actually singular in meaning and take singular verbs. Be careful with these words. These are often names of subjects, games, or countries. Also, sometimes a phrase starting with 'one of' or 'each of' leads to confusion; the verb should agree with 'one' or 'each' (which are singular), not the plural noun after 'of'.

subtopics.title: Mistakes with Plural Subjects and Singular Verbs

sections.text: A very common mistake is using a singular verb (ending in 's' or 'es') with a plural subject, especially in the simple present tense. Remember: if the subject is plural (they, we, you, or any plural noun), the verb should not have an 's' or 'es' at the end. Also, remember that 'I' and 'You' are special. Even though they are singular, they always take a plural verb form in the simple present tense (I go, you go, not I goes, you goes).
